Christ Before Herod and the High Priest

In this unusually tall, late 15th-century alabaster panel, the haloed Christ, with forked beard and bound hands, is at the centre of the composition. Fastened with a brooch around Christ's shoulders is a cloak, presumably representing the 'gorgeous robe' put upon him by the soldiers (Luke 23:11). The figure to the left in short tunic and hood, is putting a reed into Christ's left hand (although Matthew 27:29 specifies his right hand). Two figures wearing short gowns and hood turbans, the righthand figure wearing a codpiece, stand on ledges and hold a bent rod over Christ's head to press down the crown of thorns. At the top of the panel are three figures wearing doublets and rolled-brim hats. The central figure has his sleeves rolled up, his right hand raised and holding a staff with which to strike Christ. The two figures to either side (arms and weapons broken) were probably represented forcing down the torse on to Christ's head with staves. The torturers have the customary darkened faces, and some colouring survives in the garments' red lining and gilded edging.
